quotes.text: Nobody says, ‘You’re dying.’ You have to fool them. They have to fool themselves
all the goddam lies and liars that I have had to put up with, and all the goddam hypocrisy that I lived with all these forty years
there’s nothing else to live with except mendacity
How about these birthday congratulations, these many, many happy returns of the day, when everybody but you knows there won’t be any!
Lying, have they been lying? About the report from the - clinic? Did they, did they find something? - Cancer. Maybe?
Brick and I are going to - have a child!
Living with someone you love can be lonelier - than living entirely alone! - if the one that y’ love doesn’t love you
I can’t see a man but you! Even with my eyes closed, I just see you!
But how in hell on earth do you imagine - that you’re going to have a child by a man that can’t stand you?
And I did, I did so much, I did love you! - I even loved your hate and hardness, Big Daddy / Wouldn’t that be funny if that was true
quotes.source: Unrequited love - Big Mama and Big Daddy pg 40

quotes.text: [She kisses Brick on the mouth which he immediately wipes with the back of his hand]
I do love you, Brick, I do! / [smiling with charming sadness] Wouldn’t it be funny if that was true?
quotes.source: Unrequited love - Maggie and Brick pg 91

quotes.text: it was only Skipper that harboured even any unconscious desire for anything not perfectly pure between you two
- But Gooper and Mae suggested that there was something not right exactly in your - /  not exactly normal in your friendship with -

you call me your son and a queer. Maybe that’s why you put Maggie and me in this room that was Jack Straw’s and Peter Ochello’s, in which that pair of old sisters slept in a double bed where both of ‘em died
Why can’t exceptional friendship, real, real, deep, deep friendship! Between two men be respected as something clean and decent without being thought of as -
He, poor Skipper, went to bed with Maggie to prove it wasn’t true and when it didn’t work out, he thought it was true! - Skipper broke in two like a rotten stick
Ignorance - of mortality - is a comfort. A man don’t have that comfort, he’s the only living thing that conceives of death, that knows what it is.
quotes.source: Disease and Death - Big Daddy pg 48

quotes.text: I thought I had it. The earth shook under my foot, the sky come down like the black lid of a kettle and I couldn’t breath! - Today!! - that lid was lifted
quotes.source: Disease and Death - Big Daddy pg 54

quotes.text: Why should I turn over over twenty-eight thousand acres to not my kind…Why should I subsidise worthless behaviour…I didn’t make up my mind at all on that question and still to this day I ain’t made out no will!
quotes.source: Disease and Death - Big Daddy pg 59

quotes.text: We musn’t scream at each other, the walls in this house have ears
I want some privacy here, while I’m having a confidential talk with my son Brick … I hate eaves droppers, I don’t like any kind of sneakin’ an’ spyin’.
quotes.source: Isolation and communication - Big Daddy pg 42

quotes.text: Ever so often you say to me, Brick, I want to have a talk with you, but when we talk, it never materialises. Nothing is said … Communication is - awful hard between people
Some single men stop drinking when they git married and others start! Brick never touched liquor before he -!
[crying out] THAT’s NOT FAIR!
Mae an’ Gooper are plannin’ to freeze us out of Big Daddy’s estate because you drink and I’m childless
[Big Daddy is famous for his jokes at Big Mama’s expense…sometimes they’re pretty cruel and Big Mama has to pick up or fuss with something to cover the hurt that the loud laugh doesn’t quite cover]
They’re sittin’ in the middle of a big piece of land … and so they’re squaring off on it, determined to knock off a bigger piece of it than the other
Git away from me, git away from me, Mae! I want Brick! Where’s Brick? Where is my only son?
I’ve got a right to discuss my brother with other members of MY OWN family which don’t include you.
I’ve never seen such malice toward a brother.
I made my mistake when I told you the truth about that thing with skipper. Never should have confessed it, a fatal error, tellin’ you about that thing with Skipper
I made my mistake when I told you the truth about that thing with skipper. Never should have confessed it, a fatal error, tellin’ you about that thing with Skipper
Because I used to jump them, and people like to do what they used to do, even after they’ve stopped being able to do it
I left out a long-distance call which I had from Skipper, in which he made a drunken confession to me and on which I hung up! - last time we spoke to each other in our lives
Always had to suck up to people I couldn't stand because they had money and I was poor as Job's turkey.
You can be young without money, but you can't be old without it.
They’re sittin’ in the middle of a big piece of land … and so they’re squaring off on it, determined to knock off a bigger piece of it than the other
This is a deliberate campaign of vilification for the most disgusting and sordid reason on earth, and I know what it is! It’s avarice, avarice, greed, greed!
[to herself, downstage, hissingly]: Poisons, poisons! Venomous thoughts and words! In hearts and minds!—That's poisons!

Time goes by so fast. Nothin' can outrun it. Death commences too early—almost before you're half-acquainted with life—you meet with the other... Oh, you know we just got to love each other an' stay together, all of us, just as close as we can, especially now that such a black thing has come and moved into this place without invitation.
You! - dug the grave of your friend and kicked him in it! - before you’d face the truth with him!
Mendacity is a system that we live in. Liquor is the way out an’ death’s the other
tonight we're going to make the lie true, and when that's done, I'll bring the liquor back here and we'll get drunk together
Laws of silence don’t work
